facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 149 of 1956 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 149 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated December 22, 1954 of Nagpur High Court in Misc. Civil Case No. 36 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 22, 1954, of the former Nagpur High Court in Misc. Civil Case No. 36 of 1954.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR J. on April 25, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. April 25. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR J.-

facts.text: Appellant is sole proprietor of firm Bansilal Abirchand Kasturchand carrying business as money-lenders, dealers in shares and bullion and commission agents in Bombay, Calcutta and other places.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the sole proprietor of a firm called Bansilal Abirchand Kasturchand, which carries on business as money-lenders, dealers in shares and bullion and companymission agents in Bombay, Calcutta and other places.

facts.text: Appellant is resident of Bikaner and manages business through agents.

anchor.surface_text: He is a resident of Bikaner, and manages the business at the several places through agents.

facts.text: Agent at Bombay was Chandratan holding power-of-attorney dated May 13, 1944 conferring large powers including authority to operate bank accounts.

anchor.surface_text: During the relevant period, the agent of the firm at Bombay was one Chandratan, who held a power-of-attorney dated May 13, 1944, companyferring on him large powers of management including authority to operate on bank accounts.

facts.text: From November 15, 1944 to November 23, 1944, agent withdrew Rs. 2,30,636-4-0 from firm's bank account and applied to personal debts in speculative transactions.

anchor.surface_text: During the period, November 15, 1944, to November 23,1944, the agent withdrew from the firms bank account sums aggregating to Rs. 2,30,636-4-0, and applied them in satisfaction of his personal debts incurred in speculative transactions.

facts.text: On November 25, 1944, cashier sent telegram to appellant informing of the misappropriation.

anchor.surface_text: On November 25, 1944, the cashier of the firm sent a telegram to the appellant informing him of the true state of affairs.

facts.text: Appellant went to Bombay on December 3, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, the appellant went to Bombay on December 3, 1944,

facts.text: On December 4, 1944, appellant cancelled power-of-attorney to agent.

anchor.surface_text: and on the 4th, cancelled the power-of-attorney given to the agent,

facts.text: On December 6, 1944, appellant issued notice to agent to pay amounts withdrawn.

anchor.surface_text: and by numberice dated December 6, 1944, called upon him to pay the amounts withdrawn by him.

facts.text: On December 8, 1944, agent replied admitting misappropriation and pleading for mercy.

anchor.surface_text: The agent replied on December 8, 1944, admitting the misappropriation of the amounts and pleading for mercy.

facts.text: On January 16, 1945, appellant filed suit against agent in High Court of Bombay for Rs. 2,30,636-4-0.

anchor.surface_text: On January 16,1945, the appellant filed a suit against him in the High Court of Bombay for recovery of Rs. 2,30,636-4-0

facts.text: Suit decreed on February 20, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: and that was decreed on February 20, 1945.

facts.text: Rs. 28,000 recovered from Chandratan and adjusted towards decree.

anchor.surface_text: A sum of Rs. 28,000 was recovered from Chandratan and adjusted towards the decree

facts.text: Balance of Rs. 2,02,442-13-9 written off as irrecoverable at end of accounting year.

anchor.surface_text: and the balance of Rs. 2,02,442-13-9 was written off at the end of the accounting year as irrecoverable.

facts.text: Tribunal found amount represented loss due to misappropriation by agent Chandratan but held not trading loss citing Curtis v. J.G. Oldfield.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal found that the amount in question represented the loss sustained by the appellant owing to misappropriation by his agent, Chandratan, but held on the authority of the decision in Curtis v. J. G. Oldfield, Limited  1  that it was number a trading loss

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to High Court Nagpur on application of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On the application of the appellant, the Tribunal referred the following question of law for the decision of the High Court, Nagpur

facts.text: Question referred: Whether Rs. 2,02,442-13-9 allowable as deduction under s.10(1) or general principles or s.10(2)(xv).

anchor.surface_text: Whether the said sum of Rs. 2,02,442-13-9 being part of the amount embezzled by the assessees Munim is allowable as a deduction under the Indian Income-  1   1925  9 Tax Cas. 319. tax Act either under Section 10 1  or under the general principles of determining the profit and loss of the assessee or Section 10 2  xv  ?

facts.text: Nagpur High Court held governed by Curtis case, answered against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges held that the case was governed by the decision in Curtis v. J. G. Oldfield, Limited  1 , and answered the question against the appellant.

facts.text: Application under s.66A for certificate dismissed by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: An application under s. 66 A  2  for a certificate was also dismissed

facts.text: Appellant obtained special leave under Art. 136 to appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: and thereafter, the appellant applied for and-obtained leave to appeal to this Court under Art. 136, and that is how the appeal companyes before us.

facts.text: Supreme Court held loss incidental to business and deductible under s.10(1).

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we are of opinion that the loss sustained by the appellant as a result of misappropiriation by Chandratan is one which is incidental to the carrying, on of his business, and that it should therefore deducted in companyputing the profits under s. 10 1  of the, Act.

facts.text: Order of lower court set aside, reference answered in affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: In this view, the order of the lower companyrt must be set aside and the reference answered in the, affirmative.
and thereafter, the appellant applied for and-obtained leave to appeal to this Court under Art. 136, and that is how the appeal comes before us.
This is an appeal against the judgment of the High Court of Nagpur in a reference under s. 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, hereinafter referred to as the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is to be noted that while s. 10 1  imposes a charge on the profits or gains of a trade, it does not provide how those profits are to be computed. Section 10 2  enumerates various items which are admissible as deductions, but it is well settled that they are not exhaustive of all allowances which could be made in ascertaining profits taxable under s. 10 1 .

issues.text: Whether the said sum of Rs. 2,02,442-13-9 being part of the amount embezzled by the assessee's Munim is allowable as a deduction under the Indian Income-tax Act either under Section 10(1) or under the general principles of determining the profit and loss of the assessee or Section 10(2)(xv)?

issues.text: whether it is a trading loss, which must be taken into account in computing the profits under s. 10(1) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: that it is a trading loss, which must be taken into account in computing the profits under s. 10 1  of the Act.

issues.text: whether amounts lost through embezzlement by an employee are a trading loss which could be deducted in computing the profits of a business under s. 10(1)

anchor.surface_text: The controversy therefore narrows itself to the question whether amounts lost through embezzlement by an employee are a trading loss which could be deducted in computing the profits of a business under s. 10 1 .

Section 10 2  enumerates various items which are admissible as deductions, but it is well settled that they are not exhaustive of all allowances which could be made in ascertaining profits taxable under s. 10 1 .

arguments.claim: Loss from employee embezzlement arises from carrying on business and incidental

anchor.surface_text: Viewing the question as a businessman would, it seems difficult to maintain that it does not. A business especially such as is calculated to yield taxable profits has to be carried on through agents, cashiers, clerks and peons.

arguments.claim: Curtis distinguishable; embezzlement there de hors the trade

anchor.surface_text: Thus, what the learned Judge really finds is that the embezzlement was not connected with the carrying on of the trade but was outside it, and on that finding, the decision can only be that the deduction should be disallowed.

holdings.text: The deduction for loss sustained by reason of embezzlement is not admissible under s. 10(2)(xi) of the Act as a bad debt.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the first ground, the authorities have consistently held that the deduction is not admissible under s. 10 2  xi  of the Act, and that, in our view, is correct. A debt arises out of a contract between the parties,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bad debt requires a contractual obligation; embezzlement is fraud without contract; journal entries do not create liability.

holdings.text: The loss is not a business expense falling within s. 10(2)(xv) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Nor can a claim for deduction be admitted under s. 10 2  xv , because moneys which are withdrawn by the employee out of the business till without authority and in fraud of the proprietor can in no sense be said to be an expenditure laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purpose of the business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unauthorized and fraudulent withdrawals not laid out or expended for business purposes.

holdings.text: Losses resulting from embezzlement by an employee are admissible as deductions under s. 10(1) if they arise out of the carrying on of the business and are incidental to it.

anchor.surface_text: These being the governing principles, in deciding whether loss resulting from embezzlement by an employee in a business is admissible as a deduction under s. 10 1  what has to be considered is whether it arises out of the carrying on of the business and is incidental to it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Profits computed per ordinary commercial principles; employment of agents necessary for business carries risk of embezzlement which is incidental.

holdings.text: The loss sustained by the appellant due to misappropriation by agent Chandratan is incidental to the carrying on of his business and deductible under s. 10(1).

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we are of opinion that the loss sustained by the appellant as a result of misappropiriation by Chandratan is one which is incidental to the carrying, on of his business, and that it should therefore deducted in computing the profits under s. 10 1  of the, Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agent had authority to operate bank; withdrawals in purported exercise thereof; business as money-lender requires continuous bank operations; distinguishes Curtis on facts and business nature.

holdings.text: The order of the High Court is set aside and the reference is answered in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: In this view, the order of the lower court must be set aside and the reference answered in the, affirmative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on holding that loss is deductible under s.10(1).

holdings.text: Curtis v. J.G. Oldfield does not lay down a general rule that post-receipt embezzlement is not incidental to business; decision turns on specific facts.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, what the learned Judge really finds is that the embezzlement was not connected with the carrying on of the trade but was outside it, and on that finding, the decision can only be that the deduction should be disallowed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Curtis involved withdrawals de hors trade by managing director in non-banking business; not applicable to money-lending where bank operations are core.

anchor.surface_text: Incometax companymissioner v. chitnavis  1 , the point for decision was whether a bad debt could be deducted under s. 10(1) of the Act, there having been in the Act, as it then stood, no provision corresponding to s. 10(2)(xi) for deduction of such a debt.

precedents.cited_proposition: bad debts deductible under s.10(1) even without specific provision in s.10(2)
precedents.cited_holding: deduction of bad debts necessarily allowable to arrive at true profits

precedents.cited_proposition: profits to be understood in natural commercial sense

anchor.surface_text: Pondicherry Railway Co.v.Income-tax Commissioner  1  English authorities can only be utilized with caution in the consideration of Indian income-tax cases owing to the differences in the relevant legislation, but the principle laid down by Lord Chancellor Halsbury in Gresham Life-Assurance Society V. Styles  2

precedents.case_name: Pondicherry Railway Co v Income-tax Commissioner
precedents.cited_proposition: English authorities to be used with caution but Gresham principle of general application

precedents.citation: Jagarnath Therani v. Commissioner of Income-tax  1

anchor.surface_text: Jagarnath Therani v. Commissioner of Income-tax  1 , the facts were that the assessee who was carrying on business entrusted a sum of Rs. 25,000 to his gumastha for payment to a creditor, but he embezzled it.

precedents.case_name: Jagarnath Therani v Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: embezzlement by gumastha/employee is incidental to business and deductible

precedents.citation: Ramaswami Chettiar v. Commissioner of Income-Tax, Madras  1

anchor.surface_text: Ramaswami Chettiar v. Commissioner of Income-Tax, Madras  1 , the assessee was carrying on banking business in several places in India and in Burma. On October 21, 1926 thieves broke into the strong room in the business premises at Moulmiengyum and stole cash and currency notes of the value of Rs. 9,335.

precedents.case_name: Ramaswami Chettiar v Commissioner of Income Tax Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: theft by strangers/thieves not incidental to business, but embezzlement by employee is

precedents.citation: Bansidhar Onkarmal V. Commissioner of Incometax  1

anchor.surface_text: Bansidhar Onkarmal V. Commissioner of Incometax  1 , there was a theft of money by an accountant, but it took place after the office hours, and it was held, following the decision in Ramaswami Chettiar v. Commissioner of Income-tax  2  that it could not be allowed as a deduction under s. 10(1) of the Act

precedents.case_name: Bansidhar Onkarmal v Commissioner of Income Tax
precedents.cited_proposition: theft by employee after office hours not incidental to business

precedents.citation: Venkatachalapathy Iyer v. Commissioner of Income-tax  3

anchor.surface_text: Venkatachalapathy Iyer v. Commissioner of Income-tax  3 , the assessees were a firm of merchants engaged in the business of selling yarn. Its accountant was one Rajarathnam lyengar, whose duty it was to receive cash on sales, make disbursements and maintain accounts.

precedents.case_name: Venkatachalapathy Iyer v Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: embezzlement by accountant through falsifying accounts is incidental to business

anchor.surface_text: Curtis v.J. G. oldfield  4  somewhat closely, as the main controversy in the Indian courts has been as to what was precisely determined therein. There, the facts were that the managing director of a company who was in exclusive control of its business

precedents.citation: Lords Dairy Farm Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax  1

anchor.surface_text: Lords Dairy Farm Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax  1 . On a review of the authorities including the decision in Curtis v. J. G. Oldfield, Limited  2 , Chagla C. J. and Tendolkar J. held that loss caused to a business by defalcation of an employee was a trading loss

precedents.citation: Motipur Sugar Factory Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax  3

anchor.surface_text: Motipur Sugar Factory Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax  3 , an employee who had been entrusted with the funds of a company for purposes of distribution among sugarcane growers in accordance with statutory rules, was robbed of them on the way.
